question.content:
Mason split up the area of a rectangle to help him solve a division equation.

![area model split into 4 parts, each with a width of 3 units. From top to bottom the parts have a height of 900 units and an area of 2,700 square units; a height of 10 units and an area of 30 square units; a height of 3 units and an area of 9 square units; an unlabeled height and an area of 1 square units.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4453bcbab16222ceb5c247d4751ffad18354bdff)

**What equation did Mason solve?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

hints.content:
To find the area of the entire rectangle, we need to add the areas of the smaller rectangles that make it up.

$\purpleD{2{,}700}+\blueE{30}+\greenE{9}+\goldE{1}=\redE{2{,}740}$

The area of the entire rectangle is $\redE{2{,}740}$ square units.

 ![the same model with the combined area labeled 2,740 square units and the height labeled question mark units](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/376b4df6bfb4e6db48ef47864e25e2a18f5025f5)

Mason is dividing the area of the entire rectangle by $\tealE{3}$.  

To find the total height, we add each of the smaller heights. We know three of the heights.

$900+10+3=\maroonD{913}$ 

The leftover smaller rectangle has an area of $\goldE{1}$ square unit. That is less than $\tealE{3}$, so it is Mason's remainder.
Mason was solving the equation $\redE{2{,}740} \div \tealE{3} =\maroonD{913}$ remainder $\goldE{1}$.
